[[File:ReprezentareAntropomorpfa0000.JPG|140px|thumb|Goddess with the double triangle (hourglass) design and "bird hands".{{Citation | last = Gimbutas | first = Marija Alseikaite | author-link = Marija Gimbutas | last2 = Dexter | first2 = Miriam Robbins | title = The Living Goddesses | place = Berkeley | publisher = University of Calififornia Press | year = 1999 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Xs26aFrT0YAC&dq | pages = 286 | isbn = 0-520-21393-9 | oclc = 237345793}}]] This ritual assemblies lay in a vase that had a very anomalous shape to the Precucuteni style and were full of soil and straw. The cultic objects were put on display and worshiped during magic-religious ceremonies. The repeated use of them is proven by the presence of some chipping from wear. When not in motion, they were probably stored in this special container. The presence of soil under some statuettes kept in the vase, and the evidence of cariossids on the surface of two figurines and four stools, led some researchers to hypothesize that the pieces had been deposited in soil and straw for magical purposes: they had been left to bud. all the statues were distinct. Some of them bear geometrical decorations. There were observed mature statuettes (that have already given birth), young statuettes (that have not yet given birth), and a babies . Only the mature figurines may sit by right on clay stools. ==Bird goddess figurines== [[File:CucutenibirdGoddess.JPG|thumb|Bird Goddesses]] According to some researchers as Gimbutas, Lazarocici, for the Precucuteni communities, mythic birds possibly embodied a solar principle and the revival of the life, serving as a symbol of prosperity and protection. ==Funerary rites== One of the unanswered questions regarding the Cucuteni-Trypillia culture is the small number of artifacts associated with funerary rites. Although very large settlements have been explored by archaeologists, the evidence for mortuary activity is almost invisible. Making a distinction between the eastern Tripolye and the western Cucuteni regions of the Cucuteni-Trypillia geographical area, American archaeologist Douglass W. Bailey writes:
There are no Cucuteni cemeteries and the Tripolye ones that have been discovered are very late.
{{Cite book | last = Bailey | first = Douglass W. | title = Prehistoric figurines: representation and corporeality in the Neolithic | publisher = Routledge | year = 2005 | location = London; New York | url = http://www.routledge.com/9780415331517 | oclc = 56686499}}{{rp|page=115}} The discovery of skulls is more frequent than other parts of the body, however because there has not yet been a comprehensive statistical survey done of all of the skeletal remains discovered at Cucuteni-Trypillia sites, precise [[post excavation]] analysis of these discoveries cannot be accurately determined at this time. Some historians have contrasted the funerary practices of the Cucuteni-Trypillia culture with the neighboring [[Linear Pottery culture]], which existed from 5500-4500 BC in the region of present-day Hungary and extending westward into central Europe, making it coincide with the Precucuteni to Cucuteni A Phases. Archaeological evidence from the Linear Pottery sites have shown that they practiced [[cremation]], as well as [[inhumation]] (or burial). However, there appears to have been a distinction made in the Linear-Pottery culture on where the bodies were interred, based on gender and social dominance. Women and children were found to be buried beneath the floor of the house, while men were missing, indicating some other practice was associated with how they dealt with the dead bodies of males. One of the conclusions drawn from this evidence was espoused by Marija Gimbutas, author of ''The Civilization of the Goddess: The world of Old Europe'', in which she theorizes that women and children were associated with hearth and home, and so they would be buried beneath it as an act of connecting their bodies to the home.{{Citation | last = Gimbutas | first = Marija Alseikaitė | author-link = Marija Gimbutas | title = The civilization of the Goddess: the world of Old Europe | place = San Francisco | publisher = HarperSanFrancisco | year = 1991 | url = http://csp.org/chrestomathy/civilization_of.html | isbn = 0-06-250368-5 | oclc = 123210574}} Collectively taking these characteristics of the neighboring Linear Pottery culture into consideration, scholars have theorized that additional Cucuteni-Tryilian sites may be found, including locations that may be detached from the main settlements, where there may be evidence of the practice of cremation. Archaeologists have discussed broadening the search areas around known Cucuteni-Trypillia settlements to cover a much wider area, and to employ modern techniques to help try to find evidence of outlying sites where evidence of funerary activities could be found.{{Citation | last = Boghian | first = Dumitru D. | title = Comunitățile cucuteniene din bazinul Bahluiului (rezumat) | trans-title = The Cucutenian communities in the bahlui Basin (summary) |language=Romanian, English, French |translator=Sergiu Ruptaș |translator2=Alexandru Dan Boghian |translator3=Otilia Ignătescu |url=http://eneoliticulestcarpatic.blogspot.com/2008/04/comunitile-cucuteniene-din-bazinul_07.html | place = Suceava, Romania | publisher = Editura Bucovina Istorică şi Editura Universităţii, Universitatea "Ştefan cel Mare" Suceava (Bukovina Publishing House and University Publishing House, The "Ştefan cel Mare" University of Suceava) | year = 2004 | laydate = 7 April 2008 | accessdate = 11 December 2009}} – This is a summary written by the author of a monograph with the same title, and posted to his online blog ''Eneoliticul est-carpatic'' (Eneolithic Eastern Carpathian) In addition to cremation and burial, other possible methods of disposing of the bodies of the dead have been suggested. Romanian archaeologists Silvia Marinescu-Bîlcu and Alexandra Bolomey suggest a common practice of abandoning the body to the mercy of Mother Nature,{{Citation | last = Marinescu-Bîlcu | first = Silvia | last2 = Bolomey | first2 = Alexandra | last3 = Cârciumaru | first3 = Marin | title = Drăgușeni: a Cucutenian community | series = Archaeologia Romanica | volume = 2 | place = Bucharest | publisher = Editura Enciclopedică | year = 2000 | pages = 198 | isbn = 973-45-0329-4 | oclc = 48400843 }}{{rp|page=157}} a practice that may be somewhat similar to the [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrian]] tradition of placing the bodies of the dead on top of a [[Tower of Silence]] (or Dakhma), which are then fed upon by [[Scavenger|carrion]] birds. Russian archaeologist Tamara Grigorevna Movsha proposed a theory, in 1960, to explain the absence of some bones, as considered to have magical powers and were scattered on purpose across the settlement.{{Citation | first = Tamara Grigorevna | last = Movsha | year = 1960 | chapter = К вопросу о трипольских погребениях с обрядом трупоположения |trans-chapter=The issue of Trypillian funeral rite provisions for corpses | title = Материалы и исследования по археологии Юго-Запада СССР и Румынской Народной Республики |trans-title=Materials and research in archeology of the southwestern USSR and the Romanian People's Republic | pages = 59–76 | place = Chişinău | publisher = USSR Academy of Sciences}} Others have suggested the practices of [[cannibalism]] (known also as anthrophagy), or [[excarnation]], which is the practice of removing the flesh and organs of the dead, leaving only the bones. Romanian archaeologist Sergiu Haimovici writes about such a discovery:
''...Alexandra Bolomey...made a review{{Cite journal | last = Bolomey | first = Alexandra | title = Noi descoperiri de oase umane într-o așezare Cucuteniană |trans-title=New discovery of human bones in a Cucuteni site | journal = Cercetǎri arheologice | volume = 6 | pages = 159–173 | series = Colecția Istorie și civilizație (History and Civilization Collection) | publisher = Bucuresti Glasul Bucovinei | location = Bucharest | year = 1983 | language = Romanian | oclc = 224531079}} of a series of...human remains, (and) found...at least partly, (that) they have a [[Human sacrifice|cultic]] character and maybe even...an [[Cannibalism|antropophagy]] {{sic}} of (a) cultic type.''{{Cite journal | last = Haimovici | first = Sergiu | title = The human bone with possible marks of human teeth found at Liveni site (Cucuteni culture) | journal = Studia Antiqua et Archaeologica | volume = 9 | pages = 97–100 | publisher = Iaşi University | location = Iaşi, Romania | year = 2003 | language = English | translator-first = Monica | translator-last = Popa | url = http://cisa.uaic.ro/saa/saa9/art.7.Haimovici%20.pdf | oclc = 224741260 | accessdate = 9 December 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110813154117/http://cisa.uaic.ro/saa/saa9/art.7.Haimovici%20.pdf | archivedate = 13 August 2011 | df = dmy-all }}
This would indicate that perhaps some ritualistic cannibalism was practiced among the Cucuteni-Trypillia tribes. The only conclusion which can be drawn from archeological evidence is that in the Cucuteni-Trypillia culture, in the vast majority of cases, the bodies were not formally deposited within the settlement area.{{rp|page=116}} Still in one of few sites, where researchers have found a significant number of human remains (Poduri Dealul Ghindaru in Romania), it seems possible in analyzing the findings, that in the early Cucuteni Culture, the children and infants were inhumed near the houses or even under the house floor.{{cite web|url=http://www.bio.uaic.ro/publicatii/anale_zoologie/issue/2010/21-2010.pdf|format=PDF|title=ANATOMICAL DESCRIPTION OF HUMAN REMAINS DISCOVERED IN THE PREHISTORICAL SITE OF CUCUTENI CULTURE AT PODURI-DEALUL GHINDARU (BACĂU COUNTY, ROMANIA)|publisher=Bio.uaic.ro|accessdate=20 December 2014}} ==Cremation== {{See also|Fire sacrifice}} Various researchers have some hypotheses about Cucuteni rituals: # Incineration Ritual of Cucuteni-Trypillya houses, most probable associated with interment and immolation. # a ritual, who consider sacrifice buried under houses or on settlement, animals, their heads or parts, possibly associated with immolation ceremony.Piatra Neamt permanent exposition # a ritual, who consist in burying (by interment) under dwellings or on settlement of human skulls, bone, sometimes burnt, the deceased with stock, possibly is also associated with immolation. # Rituals, associated with use of fire, when into pit, exclusive of ashes get the various things, possibly immolation oddments. {{other uses}} {{Infobox person | name = Robert Adamson Bone | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = 1924 | birth_place = | death_date = November 25, 2007 | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Scholar | education = [[Yale University]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Robert Adamson Bone''' (1924 – November 25, 2007)<ref name="tcm4ff">{{citation|title=TC Mourns Four from Its Faculty|url=http://www.tc.edu/equitycampaign/article.asp?id=6459|series=The Campaign for Educational Equity|publisher=Teachers College, Columbia University|date=December 12, 2007|accessdate=May 14, 2012}}.</ref> was a scholar of [[African-American literature]] and a professor of English at [[Columbia University]].
==Biography== Bone was a [[conscientious objector]] during [[World War II]],<ref name="tcm4ff"/> and earned his B.A. in English from [[Yale University]] in 1945. He was National Secretary of the [[Young People’s Socialist League]] from 1946 to 1947, and then from 1947 to 1948 he worked in the automotive industry in [[Flint, Michigan]]. Returning to Yale, he earned a master's degree in [[American studies]] in 1949 and a doctorate in 1955. Bone taught at Yale and at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], before joining the faculty at [[Teachers College, Columbia University|Teachers College, Columbia]], where he taught from 1965 to 1990.<ref>{{citation|title=Robert A. Bone Collection|url=http://pocketknowledge.tc.columbia.edu/home.php/browse/27061|publisher=Teachers College, Columbia University|accessdate=May 14, 2012}}.</ref>
==Works== Bone's book ''The Negro Novel in America'', his Yale dissertation, was published in two editions in 1958 and 1965, and translated into [[Japanese language|Japanese]].<ref name="tcm4ff"/> Reviewer August Meier places it within the [[New Criticism]] movement, and calls it a "brilliant and provocative study".<ref name="meier">{{citation|title=Some Reflections on the Negro Novel|first=August|last=Meier|journal=CLA Journal|volume=2|year=1959|pages=168–177|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SWJu9ZhVThIC&pg=PA124}}.</ref> In it, Bone identifies four periods of African-American literature: a period of [[Cultural assimilation|assimilation]] into the white [[middle class]] from 1890 to 1920, the [[Cultural pluralism|pluralism]] of the [[Harlem Renaissance]] in the 1920s, a period of [[Naturalism (literature)|naturalism]] and [[Social protest novel|protest]] during the [[Great Depression]] of the 1930s, and a "revolt against protest" in the 1940s. He discusses in detail many novels from each period, reserving particular praise for [[Richard Wright (author)|Richard Wright]]'s ''[[Native Son]]'' (1940) and [[Ralph Ellison]]'s ''[[Invisible Man]]'' (1952).<ref name="meier"/>
Bone also wrote ''Down Home: A History of Afro-American Short Fiction from its Beginnings to the End of the Harlem Renaissance'' (Putnam, 1975) and a short book on ''Native Son'' author Richard Wright.<ref name="tcm4ff"/> A manuscript left unfinished at Bone's death was completed by Richard A. Courage and published as ''The Muse in Bronzeville: African American Creative Expression in Chicago, 1932-1950'' (Rutgers University Press, 2011).
Another of Bone's contributions is the name of the "[[Black Chicago Renaissance]]", a period of expansion for [[African-American culture]] in [[Chicago]] prior to World War II.<ref>{{cite book |title=Writers of the Black Chicago Renaissance |last=Tracy |first=Steven C. |page=1 |year=2011 |publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]] |isbn=978-0-252-03639-2 }}</ref>

A '''short-title catalogue''' (or catalog) is a [[bibliography|bibliographical]] resource that lists printed items in an abbreviated fashion, recording the most important words of their titles. The term is commonly encountered in the context of [[early modern period|early modern]] books, which frequently have lengthy, descriptive titles on their [[title page]]s. Many short-title catalogues are [[union catalogue]]s, listing items in the custody of multiple libraries.
Online short-title catalogues in fact tend to record complete (and therefore longer) title [[transcription (linguistics)|transcriptions]].

page.title: The Bronze Screen: 100 Years of the Latino Image in Hollywood (film)

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2012}} '''''The Bronze Screen''''' directed and produced by [[Nancy De Los Santos]], [[Susan Racho]], and [[Alberto Dominguez]], examines, analyzes, and critiques the portrayal of [[Latino (demonym)|Latinos]] in Hollywood over the course of a century.<ref>Rovi LeVasseur Andrea, http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/271876/The-Bronze-Screen-100-Years-of-the-Latino-Image-in-Hollywood/overview, "The Bronze Screen: 100 Years of the Latino Image in Hollywood (2002), June 2, 2012."</ref> Released in 2002, the documentary traces the different stereotypes evoked by Hollywood throughout the mid 19th and 20th century.<ref name=Speier>Speier, Michael. (2002). "The Bronze Screen: 100 Years of the Latino Image in Hollywood Cinema." ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''.</ref> This is done through the use of silent films and small excerpts from a variety of movie genres that feature Latinos. [[Carmen Miranda]] and [[Margarita Cansino]] (popularly known as [[Rita Hayworth]]) are a few of the many Latin actors and actresses whose careers, according to film historians, directors, and fellow actors featured in the documentary, were fabricated and highly manipulated by Hollywood.<ref name=Racho>De, L. S. N., Racho, S., De, J. W. (2002). Bronze Screen Productions., Latino Entertainment Media Institute., & Questar, Inc. ''The Bronze Screen: 100 Years of the Latino Image in Hollywood''.</ref> Furthermore, these actresses are used to illustrate the politics behind American Cinema and Latino/a negative representations in Hollywood.<ref name=Speier /> In addition to exploring stereotypes and negative representations of Latinos, ''The Bronze Screen'' also acknowledges the contribution and emergence of Latino writers, directors, cinematographers, composers, and graphic designers. [[Luis Valdez]], [[Pablo Ferro]], [[Montezuma Esparza]], and [[John Alfonzo]] are a few, among the many featured in the documentary, that have paved the way for other Latinos who want to work in the industry, as well as, portrayed Latinos in a more positive manner through their films.<ref name=Racho />
==Structure and content== The documentary is divided into twenty-one sections that consist of Hollywood's first bad guy, enter the Latin lover, if you talk like deez, the grave yard shift, escaping the depression, no seas tonto (don’t be stupid), some kind of hero, good neighbor policy, the name game, cow boys and Mexicans, the Latin lover return, the blacklist, border clashes, the Cesar returned, something's coming the sixties, meanwhile behind the camera, the "s" word, the urban greaser, from silver to bronze, and el futuro. A stereotype, actor or actress is examined in each section. The first section begins by looking at silent films and their use of Mexican men as the bad guys and Mexican women as bad girls with loose morals.<ref name=Racho />
In the sections that follow stereotypes such as the greaser, the Latin lover, the tonto (dumb), the bandido (bandit), the lazy Mexican, and the gangster are identified in various Hollywood films. The "if you talk like deez" section focuses on the Latino accent. According to the documentary the introduction of talkies ended the careers of many Latino actors. Latino males went from playing lead roles in silent films to playing supporting roles because of their accent. In "the grave yard shift" [[Lupe Vélez]] recalls her experience as an actress working the night shift. She goes on to explain that the Spanish versions of films were shot at night while the English version was shot during the day. Yet another obstacles Latinos have faced in Hollywood. Instead of focusing on stereotypes "the name game" section consist of the obstacles Latino actors and Latina actresses have had to face in regards to their names. The actors and actresses interviewed in this section all said to have experienced a moment in their careers in which their managers or someone in the industry suggested that they changed their name to something more American. They, however, refused to change their names because to them their names form part of their identities as actors and actresses. The last four sections of the documentary which include "something's coming the sixties", "meanwhile behind the camera", "from silver to bronze", and "el futuro" (the future) all examine the positive changes Latinos have made in Hollywood and the changes they continue to push for. Moreover, these last four sections show that Latinos in the film industry have redefined their role in Hollywood by producing, writing, and directing their own films.<ref name=Racho />
==Reception== The ''[[Library Journal]]'' wrote that ''The Bronze Screen'' is a fascinating documentary about the Latino in Hollywood from the first roles in the early 1900s to the present; the film could be used as a collection development tool for building a Latino film collection. The reviewer recommends the documentary for all academic and public libraries with Latin American studies and film studies collections. They noted that some of the comprehensive methods used include the filmmakers interviewing 15 actors, including [[Edward James Olmos]] and [[Rita Moreno]]. The review further explains, ten people that work in production positions behind the scenes are interviewed, including [[Gregory Nava]], director of ''[[Selena]]''. The writer goes on to say that the four film scholars interviewed offered insights into the stereotypes and the past and future of Latinos in the American cinema industry.<ref name=Johnston>Johnston, Lisa N. Ed. Fox, Bette-Lee. (2003). "The Bronze Screen (Film)". ''[[Library Journal]]'', 128, 131.</ref>
They wrote that the ethnic stereotypes portrayed in the documentary include the greaser, the lazy Mexican, the dark mysterious lady, the Latin lover, the spitfire, the violent gang leader, and the non-English-speaking cleaning woman. They also write that the film's structure in chapters give the film continuity, featuring a myriad of clips and stills, both familiar and rare, along with exceptional sound and film quality.<ref name=Johnston />
The ''[[School Library Journal]]'' described the film as, "compelling, enlightening, and entertaining."<ref name=Moxley>Moxley, Melody. Ed. Mandell, Phyllis Levy. (2003). "The Bronze Screen". ''[[School Library Journal]]'', 49, 62-62.</ref> ''The Bronze Screen'' relates the contributions made by Latinos to movies, from silent to contemporary films, with examples of the many ways Latinos have been portrayed. They elaborated on the film's format: "The loosely chronological structure allows viewers to compare and contrast the films and those who inhabit and create them".<ref name=Moxley /> The reviewer emphasizes part of the significance of this film: "No look at the history of Hollywood would be complete without this documentary, which should be widely viewed by anyone interested in the history of movies".<ref name=Moxley />
The writer explains that the documentary gives their view of the past and how the images of Latinos in Hollywood have shifted over time. The reviewer further describes the way in which the various stereotypes that have developed and evolved (such as the Latin Lover and the greaser) in American cinema are explored and enhanced with examples throughout the documentary. The reviewer also underlines that other film historians provide cogent commentary throughout.<ref name=Moxley />
Journalist Robert Dominguez gives his review of the film in the "Que Pasa" (what's happening) section of the newspaper, the ''[[New York Daily News]]'': "As a documentary chronicling a little-known and underappreciated aspect of film history, ''The Bronze Screen: 100 Years of the Latino Image in Hollywood Cinema'' is as comprehensive as its title suggests".<ref name=Dominguez>Dominguez, Robert. (2003). "The Latin Role in H’wood." ''[[New York Daily News]]''. http://articles.nydailynews.com/2003-0227/entertainment/18221848_1_latino-history-latino-themed-silent-era</ref> Occupying the seat as the main highlight of Harlem's 2003 Film Festival, the writer says, "Yet the main appeal of "The Bronze Screen" is what co-producer Nancy De Los Santos jokingly calls its "No s--!" factor—fascinating tidbits of information "that make people go, ‘No s--! I didn’t know that’".<ref name=Dominguez /> The review highlights the scholarship that was done by the film's creators De Los Santos, along with co-producers Alberto Dominguez and Susan Racho, who spent more than 10 years researching and making The Bronze Screen. The writer quotes De Los Santos saying, "The three of us have worked in Hollywood for 25 years, yet we didn’t even know the history of all the wonderful contributions Latinos have made".<ref name=Dominguez /> The review further quotes De Los Santos: "There are a lot of surprises for everybody in this film".<ref name=Dominguez /> These include the fact that it was two Mexican brothers that designed the movable [[King Kong]] model in the 1931 film. The writer describes other examples like these from the film, like some of the classic horror films, such as ''[[Dracula]]'' were filmed in Spanish-language versions on the same set in the middle of the night after the American cast and crew went home. Another example includes the political economics of the early 20th century: "a fed-up Mexican government that boycotted Hollywood films in the 1920s because Mexicans were constantly being portrayed as rapists, killers and outlaws".<ref name=Dominguez /> The review quotes De Los Santos saying, "People think of us as playing maids and gang members and all the other negative images. We wanted to reveal all the positive things we’ve done as a community".<ref name=Dominguez /> De Los Santos further reveals, "What I loved most about doing this is that it's Latinos documenting Latino history".<ref name=Dominguez />
Journalist Michael Speier reviews the documentary for the newspaper, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'': "The documentary covers the politics behind early distribution patterns, and the manipulation of actors, among other topics".<ref name=Speier /> The reviewer notes that a respectable amount of time is spent highlighting contributions made by multiple job levels and sectors, from composers, d.p.'s, to graphic designers. The writer notes that among the film's chapters, there's "The Graveyard Shift," describing producers’ early inclinations to shoot two separate language versions, "with the Spanish-speaking thesps and crew coming in at night and working until morning".<ref name=Speier /> Speier expands that the chapter, "Escaping the Depression," talks of the subtle shift in the dominant portrayal of Latinos: "during the 1930s toward playing Hispanics only as wealthy South Americans who comprise a fantasy world inhabited by "attractive" performers like [[Dolores del Río|Del Rio]]".<ref name=Speier /> He goes on to mention the relationship between the Hollywood film industry and the president's administration of foreign policy in the documentary's chapter, "Hollywood's First Bad Guy," where, "President [[Woodrow Wilson]] is cheekily cited for helping trade relations by imploring studios to ‘be a little kinder to the Mexicans’ after Latin America banned films that made its people dumb and violent ‘greasers’".<ref name=Speier />
Speier criticizes that the documentary does not spend enough time on the vital periods it covers. Speier adds while, "[[Ricardo Montalbán]]," one of the actors interviewed, "refused to be renamed Ricky Martin, yet his views on prejudice—and he must have some—are not fully developed".<ref name=Speier /> Speier goes on to say, "[[Anthony Quinn]] left for Europe after his ''[[Viva Zapata]]'' Oscar because he was more "accepted" there, as most Latino thesps are, yet that collective trek is almost completely ignored".<ref name=Speier /> Speier also critiques that there are several big names missing from the documentary, including Jennifer Lopez, Andy García and Selma Hayek.<ref name=Speier />
Journalist Bob Graham for the newspaper, the ''[[SFGate]]'' reviews this documentary, whose screening opened up the 9th Annual Festival Cine Latino in 2001. Graham describes the documentary as, "a history of Latino contribution to American film".<ref name=Graham>Graham, Bob. (2001). "’Bronze Screen’ focus of Cine Latino/Documentary sets tone for film festival." ''[[SFGate]]''. http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2001/09/10/DD2898.DTL</ref> The review highlights how several actors talk about how they refused to change their name to something less ethnic, but that there were others who did, for example, [[Rita Hayworth]].<ref name=Graham />
The writer further describes the actress’ transformation: "as one of the most glamorous starts of American movies, [[Hayworth]]'s heritage—concealed by the studios during her heyday in the 1940s—has since become the subject verging on myth. The review describes how the myth motivated physical changes: "She kept that name for her first 10 movies when, according to the documentary, she was "de-Latinized" and turned into the glamorous figure we remember today. Her name was changed and her hair lightened".<ref name=Graham />
In an interview from 2009 on ''[[LatinoLA]]'', De Los Santos was asked what she considered to be her greatest work so far. She responded: "While I do love all the work I have written or produced, I think the contribution of the feature-length documentary is a huge contribution to our history and the Latino legacy in Hollywood. I am very proud of that documentary".<ref>Carlos, Al Hernandez. (2009). "Nancy De Los Santos: a Latina Writer, Period." ''LatinoLA''. http://latinola.com/story.php?story=8051</ref>
==Popular ratings== The review from the website, [[Rotten Tomatoes]] says that 56% of the audience liked ''The Bronze Screen: 100 Years of the Latino Image in Hollywood''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/bronze_screen_100_years_of_the_latino_image_in_hollywood/ |title=The Bronze Screen: 100 Years of the Latino Image in Hollywood |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |date=January 7, 2003 |accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref>
Sixty-eight percent of users on the [[IMDb]] website gave the documentary a rating of 7.1 on a 10-point scale.<ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338817/</ref>
==Awards== According to the website, ''8 Ways to Say'', "''The Bronze Screen'' was nominated for the [[National Council of La Raza]]'s [[ALMA Award]] for ‘Best Documentary’".<ref>’’8 Ways to Say’’. "Nancy De Los Santos Reza." http://8waystosay.com/aboutus/nancy-de-los-santos-reza/</ref>
==Cast== The cast includes [[Benicio del Toro]], [[Anthony Quinn]], [[Dolores del Río]], [[Pablo Ferro]], [[Pablo Almodóvar]], [[María Conchita Alonso]], [[Alfonso Arau]], [[Desi Arnaz]], [[Rubén Blades]], [[Leo Carrillo]], [[José Ferrer]], [[Mel Ferrer]], [[Gael García Bernal]], [[Rita Hayworth]], [[Raúl Juliá]], [[Katy Jurado]], [[John Leguizamo]], [[Diego Luna]], [[Cheech Marin]], [[Carmen Miranda]], [[Ricardo Montalbán]], [[Esai Morales]], [[Antonio Moreno]], [[Rita Moreno]], [[Gregory Nava]], [[Romano Navarro]], [[Edward James Olmos]], [[Lupe Ontiveros]], [[Elizabeth Peña]], [[Gilbert Roland]], [[Cesar Romero]], [[Henry Silva]], [[Jimmy Smits]], [[Raquel Torres]], [[Lupita Tovar]], [[Luis Valdez]], [[Lupe Vélez]], and [[Raquel Welch]].<ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt03388417/fullcredits#cast IMDb, "Full cast and crew".</ref>
==Crew== The making of this documentary could not have been possible without the participation and contribution of the many directors, writers, graphic designers, cinematographers, composers, and film scholars interviewed. The crew includes Wanda De Jesus, Nancy De Los Santos, [[Alberto Dominguez]], [[Susan Racho]], [[José Cancela]], [[Pablo Ferro]], [[Mark Hurwitz]], [[Aida Yohannes]], [[Luca Bentivoglio]], [[Gabriela Gonzalez]], [[Luis D. Ortiz|Luis Ortiz]], and [[Efrain Osorio]].<ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1307844/fullcredits IMDb, "Full cast and crew for "Voces" The Bronze Screen (2006)", June 3, 2012.</ref>
==Further reading== Profesora [[Rosa-Linda Fregoso]], a Latin American and [[Latino Studies]] (LALS) professor at [[University of California, Santa Cruz]], gives her scholarly insights in the documentary. Nine years after the publishing of her 1993 book, ''[[The Bronze Screen: Chicana and Chicano Film Culture]]'', the documentary releases, covering many of the same Latino themes.<ref>Fregoso, Rosa-Linda. (1993). ''The Bronze Screen: Chicana and Chicano Film Culture''. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press.</ref>

For the history of women in the United States, please see [[History of women in the United States]].
== Laws ==
===Convention to Eliminate All Forms of Discrimination Against Women=== The United States has never ratified the U.N.'s [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women]], although it played an important role in drafting the treaty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/03/08/opinion/baldez-womens-equality-treaty/|title=U.S. drops the ball on women's rights - CNN|last=CNN|first=By Lisa Baldez, Special to|date=|website=cnn.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cedaw2014.org/index.php/whats-in-it-for-us|title=cedaw2014.org – Just another WordPress site|author=|date=|website=cedaw2014.org|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> As of 2014, the United States is thus one of only seven nations which have not ratified it – also including Iran, Palau, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, and Tonga.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cedaw2014.org/index.php/about-cedaw|title=cedaw2014.org – Just another WordPress site|author=|date=|website=cedaw2014.org|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
===Equal Rights Amendment=== The United States has ratified the [[Equal Rights Amendment]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/|title=ERA: Home|author=|date=|website=www.equalrightsamendment.org|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Marriage === Child marriage, as defined by [[UNICEF]], is observed in the United States. The UNICEF definition of child marriage includes couples who are formally married, or who live together as a sexually active couple in an informal union, with at least one member — usually the girl — being less than 18 years old. <ref name="Child Marriage">[http://www.unicef.org/protection/57929_58008.html Child Marriage] UNICEF (2011)</ref><ref name="icrwchild">[http://www.icrw.org/what-we-do/adolescents/child-marriage Child Marriage] ICRW (2010)</ref> The latter practice is more common in the United States, and it is officially called [[cohabitation]]. Laws regarding child marriage vary in the different states of the United States. Generally, children 16 and over may marry with parental consent, with the age of 18 being the minimum in all but two states to marry without parental consent. Those under 16 generally require a court order in addition to parental consent.<ref>{{Citation|title=www.usmarriagelaws.com|url=http://www.usmarriagelaws.com/search/united_states/}}</ref>
===Parental leave=== The United States is the only high income country not to provide required paid [[parental leave]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/23/your-money/us-trails-much-of-the-world-in-providing-paid-family-leave.html|title=In Paid Family Leave, U.S. Trails Most of the Globe|date=February 22, 2013|accessdate=2013-05-07|publisher=New York Times}}</ref>
===Reproductive rights=== {{main|Birth control in the United States}} [[Birth control]] is legal nationwide as of 2014.<ref name="lobby.la.psu.edu">{{cite web|url=http://lobby.la.psu.edu/013_Contraceptive_Coverage/organizational_statements/Planned_Parenthood/Planned_Parenthood_The_Impact_of_Legal_Birth_Control.htm|title=Griswold v. Connecticut, The Impact of Legal Birth Control and the Challenges that Remain|last=|first=|date=May 2000|website=Planned Parenthood Federation of America|publisher=Katharine Dexter McCormick Library|accessdate=July 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name="rhrealitycheck">{{cite web|url=http://rhrealitycheck.org/article/2013/03/22/today-marks-the-41st-anniversary-of-legal-contraception-for-single-people/|title=Eisenstadt v. Baird: The 41st Anniversary of Legal Contraception for Single People|last=Dunlap|first=Bridgette|date=March 22, 2013|publisher=RH Reality Check|accessdate=May 25, 2012}}</ref> [[Abortion in the United States|Abortion is legal nationwide]] as of 2014; however, states are allowed to place regulations on abortion which fall short of prohibition after the first trimester of pregnancy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0410_0113_ZS.html|title=Roe v. Wade|date=|publisher=Law.cornell.edu|accessdate=October 31, 2012}}</ref><ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/us/abortion-rate-in-1994-hit-a-20-year-low.html|title=Abortion Rate in 1994 Hit a 20-Year Low|last=|first=|date=January 5, 1997|accessdate=July 12, 2014|publisher=The New York Times Company|website=The New York Times}}</ref>
==Politics== The first woman elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]] was in 1917, [[Jeannette Rankin]], she represented Montana. In 1978 the first woman was elected to the [[United States Senate]]. Women who served before her were finishing someone else's term who died in office or had resigned.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/03/21/595702178/mississippi-is-sending-its-first-woman-to-congress-heres-when-your-state-did-tha|title=Mississippi Is Sending Its First Woman To Congress. Here's When Your State Did That|author=|date=March 21, 2018|newspaper=[[National Public Radio]]|accessdate=2018-03-21|agency=|quote=}}</ref>
Currently (August 2014), there are 79 female representatives in the United States, making up 18% of the U.S. House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cawp.rutgers.edu/fast_facts/levels_of_office/Current_Numbers.php|title=Current numbers - all levels of office|date=|publisher=Cawp.rutgers.edu|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref><ref name="indiana1">{{cite web|url=http://congress.indiana.edu/members-congress-questions-and-answers|title=Members of Congress Questions and Answers | The Center On Congress at Indiana University|date=1984-01-01|publisher=Congress.indiana.edu|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref> There are also 20 female senators in the United States, making up 20% of the U.S. Senate.<ref name="indiana1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/07/women-senate-2012-election_n_2086093.html|title=Historic Number Of Women To Serve In Next Senate|last=Terkel|first=Amanda|date=November 7, 2012|work=Huffington Post}}</ref> There are currently 3 women in the United States presidential cabinet, including: Department of Health and Human Services Secretary [[Sylvia Mathews Burwell]], Department of the Interior Secretary [[Sally Jewell]], and Department of Commerce Secretary [[Penny Pritzker]]. As for women in positions that have the status of Cabinet-rank there are also 3 women: Environmental Protection Agency Administrator [[Gina McCarthy]], United States Mission to the United Nations Ambassador [[Samantha Power]], and Small Business Administration Administrator [[Maria Contreras-Sweet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/cabinet|title=The Cabinet | The White House|date=2013-04-01|publisher=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref> Two of the three Deputy Chiefs of Staff are women, [[Anita Decker Breckenridge]] and [[Kristie Canegallo]].<ref name="whitehouse1">{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/staff|title=White House Staff | The White House|date=2013-04-01|publisher=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref> One of two Senior Advisors is also a woman, [[Valerie Jarrett]].<ref name="whitehouse1"/> The [[First Lady]] is [[Melania Trump]] and the [[Second Lady]] is [[Karen Pence]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/first-lady-michelle-obama|title=First Lady Michelle Obama | The White House|date=|publisher=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/jill-biden|title=Dr. Jill Biden | The White House|date=|publisher=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref>
== Rankings ==
===Gender equality ranking=== As of 2017, the United States is ranked 49th of 142 applicable countries in gender equality on the [[World Economic Forum]]'s [[Gender Gap Index]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/india-slides-gender-equality-global-ranking-26501431|title=India Slides, US Gains in Gender Equality Ranking|work=ABC News}}</ref>
==Religion== The United States has [[Freedom of religion in the United States|freedom of religion]] as a constitutionally guaranteed right. [[Christianity]] claims the largest number of adherents.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/govbeat/wp/2014/06/04/the-second-largest-religion-in-each-state/|title=The second-largest religion in each state|last=Wilson|first=Reid|date=4 June 2014|website=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/first_amendment|title=First Amendment|last=Staff|first=LII|date=5 February 2010|website=LII / Legal Information Institute|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Not all religious denominations ordain women, and a few (most notably [[Roman Catholicism]]) oppose artificial [[contraception]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/christianity/christianethics/contraception_1.shtml|title=BBC - Religions - Christianity: Contraception|author=|date=|website=bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cnsnews.com/news/article/michael-w-chapman/catholic-bishop-woman-ordained-priest-automatically-excommunicated|title=Catholic Bishop: Woman ‘Ordained’ as Priest Is Automatically Excommunicated|author=|date=|website=CNS News|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Many oppose [[abortion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2013/01/16/religious-groups-official-positions-on-abortion/|title=Religious Groups’ Official Positions on Abortion|author=|date=16 January 2013|website=pewforum.org|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
== Statistics ==
===Education=== As of 2014, women in the United States earn more post-secondary (college and graduate school) degrees than men do.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2014/jul/18/mitch-mcconnell/mitch-mcconnell-says-more-women-graduate-college-m/|title=Mitch McConnell says more women graduate from college than men do|date=|publisher=PolitiFact|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref>
===Marriage=== As of 2013, the most recent year for which statistics are available, average [[age at first marriage]] in the United States is 27 for women and 29 for men.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/sexes/archive/2013/03/getting-married-later-is-great-for-college-educated-women/274040/|title=Getting Married Later Is Great for College-Educated Women - Eleanor Barkhorn|last=Editors|first=The|date=2013-03-15|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref> ===Workforce=== As of 2014, women are 46.5% of the total United States workforce.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.womenscareerchannel.com/in-the-workplace/aug-2014-diversity-jobs-report-women-make-up-46-5-of-workforce/|title=Aug 2014 Diversity Jobs Report: Women Make Up 46.5% of Workforce - WCC Blog|author=|date=|website=blog.womenscareerchannel.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
Sex discrimination has been outlawed in non-ministerial employment in the United States since 1964 nationwide; however, under a judicially created doctrine called the "ministerial exemption," religious organizations are immune from sex discrimination suits brought by "ministerial employees," a category that includes such religious roles as priests, imams or kosher supervisors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/exhibits/featured_documents/amendment_19/ |title=Featured Document: The 19th Amendment |publisher=Archives.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="ministerial">{{cite web| url=http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4247&context=flr| title=Above the Law? The Constitutionality of the Ministerial Exemption from Antidiscrimination Law| date=2007| publisher= Fordham Law Review, Volume 75, Issue 4, Article 3| author=Caroline Mala Corbin|accessdate=May 25, 2012}}</ref>
A woman's median salary in the United States has increased over time, although as of 2014 it is only 77% of man's median salary, a phenomenon often referred to as the [[Gender pay gap in the United States|Gender Pay Gap]]. (A woman's average salary is reported as 84% of a man's average salary.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2014/jan/29/barack-obama/barack-obama-state-union-says-women-make-77-cents-/|title=Barack Obama, in State of the Union, says women make 77 cents for every dollar a man earns|author=|date=|website=politifact.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1983185,00.html | work=Time | first=Laura | last=Fitzpatrick | title=Why Do Women Still Earn Less Than Men? | date=April 20, 2010}}</ref> Whether this is due to discrimination is very hotly disputed, while economists and sociologists have provided evidence both supporting<ref>{{cite web|author=Men and Women of the Corporation: New Edition |url=https://www.amazon.com/Women-Corporation-Rosabeth-Moss-Kanter/dp/0465044549 |title=Kanter, ''Men and Women of the Corporation'', Basic Books, 1977 |publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://clinton4.nara.gov/WH/EOP/CEA/html/gendergap.html#disc |title=Office of the White House, Council of Economic Advisors, 1998, IV. Discrimination |publisher=Clinton4.nara.gov |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.policyalmanac.org/economic/archive/pay_equity.pdf |title=Levine, Report for Congress, "The Gender Gap and Pay Equity: Is Comparable Worth the Next Step?", Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress, 2003 |format=PDF |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> and debunking<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/02/01/no-women-don-t-make-less-money-than-men.html | work=The Daily Beast | first=Christina Hoff | last=Sommers | title=No, Women DON'T Make Less Money than Men | date=February 1, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303532704579483752909957472 | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Perry, Mark J. | last=Biggs, Andrew G. | title=The '77 Cents on the Dollar' Myth About Women's Pay | date=April 7, 2014}}</ref> this assertion.
== Violence == {{main|Violence against women in the United States}} Violence against women has been recognized as a public health concern in the United States.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Wright|first=Paul J.|last2=Tokunaga|first2=Robert S.|date=May 2016|title=Men's Objectifying Media Consumption, Objectification of Women, and Attitudes Supportive of Violence Against Women|url=|journal=[[Archives of Sexual Behavior]]|volume=45|issue=4|pages=955-964|via=}}</ref> [[Culture]] in the country has promoted the [[Minimisation (psychology)|trivialization]] women-directed violence, with media in the United States creating the appearance of violence against women unimportant to the public.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Stankiewicz|first=Julie M.|last2=Rosselli|first2=Francine|date=2008|title=Women as Sex Objects and Victims in Print Advertisements|url=|journal=[[Sex Roles (journal)|Sex Roles]]|volume=58|issue=7-8|pages=579-589|via=}}</ref>
The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] and the [[National Institute of Justice]] reports that about 1 in every 4 women suffer from at least one physical assault experience from a partner during adulthood.<ref name="VAWA2005">[http://nnedv.org/docs/Policy/VAWA2005FactSheet.pdf ''The Violence Against Women Act of 2005, Summary of Provisions.''] National Network to End Domestic Violence. Retrieved 2011-11-20.</ref> About 20% of women in the United States have been victims of [[rape]]<ref>[http://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles/172837.pdf Prevalence, Incidence, and Consequences of Violence Against Women: Findings From the National Violence Against Women Survey]. (PDF) . Retrieved on 2011-10-01.</ref><ref name="dfr-ic-fr-report">{{cite web|url=https://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/grants/219181.pdf|title=Drug-facilitated, Incapacitated, and Forcible Rape: A National Study|last1=Kilpatrick|first1=Dean G.|last2=Resnick|first2=Heidi S.|date=July 2007|website=[[National Criminal Justice Reference Service]]|publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]]|pages=43–45|format=PDF|accessdate=16 March 2015|last3=Ruggiero|first3=Kenneth J.|last4=Conoscenti|first4=Lauren M.|last5=McCauley|first5=Jenna}}</ref> with many incidents of rape being underreported according to a 2013 study.<ref name="National Research Council 2013">National Research Council.
